title: Atlas Command Load Statuses
summary: Authoritative list of Atlas Command load statuses.
body:
# Atlas Command Load Statuses

Atlas Command uses the following authoritative load statuses:

1. **AVAILABLE** – Load is created and visible for planning.
2. **PENDING_PICKUP** – Driver assigned and heading to shipper.
3. **IN_TRANSIT** – Load picked up and in motion.
4. **DELIVERED** – Delivered physically but still under review.
5. **READY_FOR_BILLING** – Documentation complete and verified.
6. **PROBLEM** – Exception state for breakdowns, refusals, delays.
7. **CANCELLED** – Load cancelled before completion.

Invalid statuses to correct:
- DISPATCHED
- PICKED_UP
- ENROUTE / ON THE WAY
- AT_SHIPPER / AT_RECEIVER
- INVOICED / PAID

PROBLEM and CANCELLED are exception paths, not workflow steps.

title: Load Lifecycle
summary: Explains the end-to-end lifecycle of a load in Atlas.
body:
# Load Lifecycle

The standard lifecycle in Atlas Command follows:

**AVAILABLE → PENDING_PICKUP → IN_TRANSIT → DELIVERED → READY_FOR_BILLING**

### AVAILABLE
Load created, visible to dispatch.

### PENDING_PICKUP
Driver assigned, in route to pickup.

### IN_TRANSIT
Pickup complete.

### DELIVERED
Freight delivered.

### READY_FOR_BILLING
POD verified, documentation complete.

### PROBLEM (Exception)
Breakdowns, delays, refusals.

### CANCELLED (Exception)
Load cancelled before completion.

title: Load Board
summary: Explains how the Load Board displays and organizes loads.
body:
# Load Board

The Load Board shows operational loads across all statuses.

Displays loads in the following categories:
- AVAILABLE
- PENDING_PICKUP
- IN_TRANSIT
- DELIVERED
- READY_FOR_BILLING
- PROBLEM
- CANCELLED

title: Driver Assignment Workflow
summary: Step-by-step process for assigning a driver.
body:
# Driver Assignment Workflow

1. Load created (AVAILABLE)
2. Dispatcher assigns driver
3. Load becomes PENDING_PICKUP
4. Driver picks up → IN_TRANSIT
5. Delivery → DELIVERED

title: Exceptions Workflow
summary: How Atlas handles breakdowns, refusals, and delays.
body:
# Exceptions Workflow

Exceptions route loads into **PROBLEM** state.

Common causes:
- Mechanical breakdown
- Shipper delay
- Receiver refusal

Loads may rejoin normal lifecycle once resolved.

title: Appointment
summary: Defines appointment scheduling requirements for shippers/receivers.
body:
# Appointment

Appointments control pickup and delivery timing.

Key elements:
- Date & time
- Facility instructions
- Driver requirements

title: Bill of Lading (BOL)
summary: Defines a Bill of Lading and its required elements.
body:
# Bill of Lading (BOL)

A BOL is the primary shipping document establishing:
- Freight description
- Pickup details
- Legal terms
- Signatures at origin

title: Proof of Delivery (POD)
summary: Defines POD and how it drives billing readiness.
body:
# POD

A Proof of Delivery captures:
- Receiver signature
- Delivery timestamp
- Freight condition notes

Required before READY_FOR_BILLING.

title: Document Handling Requirements
summary: Defines required documents and handling rules for each load.
body:
# Document Handling Requirements

Each Load may require one or more documents:

- Bill of Lading (BOL)
- Proof of Delivery (POD)
- Rate confirmation
- Accessorial proof (receipts, notes)

Before a Load can move to **READY_FOR_BILLING**:
- All required documents must be attached
- Documents must be legible
- Names, dates, and signatures must be visible

Missing or poor-quality documents delay billing and may block invoice creation.

title: Accessorials
summary: Defines accessorials and how they are documented for billing.
body:
# Accessorials

Accessorials are additional charges for services beyond standard linehaul.

Common examples:
- Detention
- Layover
- TONU (Truck Ordered Not Used)
- Lumper fees
- Driver assist
- Redelivery

Accessorials must be:
- Noted on the Load
- Supported by receipts or time stamps when possible
- Reviewed during **READY_FOR_BILLING** before invoicing.

title: Accessorial Charges
summary: Breaks down common accessorial types and their billing rules.
body:
# Accessorial Charges

Accessorial charges are billed as separate line items on the Invoice.

Typical charge types:
- Detention: charge per hour after free time
- Layover: charge per day
- TONU: flat fee for unused truck
- Lumper: pass-through or marked-up fee
- Driver Assist: per-event or hourly

Billing best practices:
- Confirm customer rules before applying
- Attach proof (receipts, notes)
- Ensure accessorials are clearly labeled on the Invoice

title: Ready for Billing
summary: Defines when a Load becomes READY_FOR_BILLING and what it means operationally.
body:
# Ready for Billing

A Load becomes **READY_FOR_BILLING** once operational work is complete and documents are verified.

Requirements:
- Load status is **DELIVERED**
- POD is uploaded and legible
- Required documents (BOL, accessorial proof, etc.) are present
- No open operational issues remain

READY_FOR_BILLING means:
- The Load is locked from normal operational editing
- Billing can generate an Invoice
- The Load appears in the billing queue

READY_FOR_BILLING is a **load status**, not a financial state like Invoiced or Paid.

title: Invoice
summary: Explains what an Invoice is and when it is created from a Load.
body:
# Invoice

An Invoice is the financial document created from a **READY_FOR_BILLING** Load.

An Invoice includes:
- Customer and remit-to details
- Linehaul and accessorial charges
- References (load number, PO, BOL, etc.)
- Attached documents such as POD

Key points:
- Invoice creation happens **after** READY_FOR_BILLING
- Invoice is not a Load status
- Payment is tracked against Invoices, not directly against Loads

title: Payment
summary: Defines payment and how it relates to Invoices and Loads.
body:
# Payment

Payment is money received from the customer in response to an Invoice.

Payment lifecycle is **financial**, not operational:
- Invoice generated
- Invoice sent to customer
- Customer processes payment
- Payment received and applied

Load statuses stop at **READY_FOR_BILLING**. Payment does not change the Load status; it updates financial records.

title: Document
summary: General definition of documents in Atlas Command.
body:
# Document (General)

A document in Atlas Command is any file or record attached to a Load or account.

Examples:
- BOL
- POD
- Rate confirmation
- Accessorial receipts

Documents support:
- Operational accuracy
- Billing readiness
- Audits and disputes

title: Workflow
summary: Defines what a workflow is in the context of Atlas Command.
body:
# Workflow

A workflow is a repeatable sequence of steps that moves a Load or process from start to finish.

Atlas workflows include:
- Load lifecycle
- Driver assignment
- Exceptions handling
- Billing readiness

Workflows are designed to be:
- Predictable
- Auditable
- Safe for AI assistance

title: Role
summary: Defines user roles and responsibility boundaries.
body:
# Role

A role represents a set of permissions and responsibilities within Atlas Command.

Examples:
- Dispatcher
- Driver Manager
- Billing Specialist
- Admin

Roles determine:
- Which pages a user can access
- Which actions they can take
- What data they can see

title: Atlas AI Governance (Dipsy Constitution)
summary: Defines the governance rules and constraints for AI behavior in Atlas Command.
body:
# Atlas AI Governance (Dipsy Constitution)

This document defines the governance rules for all Atlas AI components.

Core principles:
- Enforce canonical load statuses and workflows
- Respect Row-Level Security and org boundaries
- Never hallucinate undocumented features or statuses
- Prefer "This is not documented in Atlas yet" over guessing

AI agents must:
- Use docs and tools as ground truth
- Avoid cross-org data leakage
- Follow safe workflows (no skipping READY_FOR_BILLING rules)
- Support auditability by logging key actions where appropriate
